newsitem.title: UK: Politicians and psychopaths cut from same cloth?.
newsitem.headline: Politicians and psychopaths cut from same cloth?.

text.p: Politicians and criminal psychopaths share some important behavioural characteristics, a leading British psychologist said on Wednesday.
"Psychopaths lie easily. They get pleasure from duping people whereas politicians lie for a purpose," David Cook, a lecturer at Glasgow's Caledonian University, told Reuters.

Cook and graduate student, Lisa Marshall, presented the findings of a three-year study on the causes of psychopathic behavior to the British Psychological Society's annual conference in York, northern England.
They interviewed 105 repeat offenders in Scottish prisons and found that a combination of social and biological factors contributed to psychopathic behaviour.

"Difficult childhoods tended to be a common thread," Cook said, adding that the purpose of the study was not to discover if politicians were psychopaths but to understand what factors triggered the behaviour.
"To say politicians are psychopaths is a bit of a distortion," Cook said, but he acknowledged that the two groups appeared to share some similar behaviour patterns.
"Psychopaths tend to be grandiose, they don't feel remorse, they don't feel guilt and they don't maintain stable relationships," he added.
Marshall said people in high-powered careers such as politics and stockbroking shared enough characteristics to be defined as psychopathic.
"They have the characteristics of psychopaths but without the criminal intent," she told the conference on Tuesday.
Cook believes it will be difficult to scientifically prove that to be a successful politician or stockbroker a person needs to be a psychopath.
"The trouble is there just isn't any data. Politicians and stockbrokers don't like to be studied," Cook said.
